title: FAB
description: The FAB represents the most important action on a screen. It puts key actions within reach.

contentChunks.htmlValue: There are three sizes of floating action buttons: FAB, small FAB, and large FAB.

contentChunks.footer:
1. FAB
2. Small FAB
3. Large FAB
contentChunks.altText: 3 FAB sizes

contentChunks.htmlValue: Resources

TypeLinkStatus
 DesignDesign kit (Figma)
Available
M2 guideline – Buttons: floating action buttonAvailable
ImplementationMDC-AndroidAvailable
Jetpack ComposeAvailable
FlutterAvailable
Web Planned
Takeaways

• Use a FAB for the most common or important action on a screen
  • Icons in a FAB must be clear and understandable since these buttons do not have a text label
  • The FAB should persist on the screen when content is scrolling
What's new

• Color: New color mappings and compatibility with dynamic color
  • Shape: Boxier style with smaller corner radius
  • Types: New large FAB variation

contentChunks.footer: FABs have updated colors, shapes, and sizes.
contentChunks.altText: 4 examples of M3 FABs

contentChunks.footer: M2: FABs are circles and always have a drop shadow.
contentChunks.altText: Circular M2 FAB

contentChunks.footer: M3: FABs have a boxier shape, can use dynamic color, and include a new large FAB variation.
contentChunks.altText: A more box-shaped M3 FAB

contentChunks.htmlValue:

FAB color

Color values are implemented through design tokens. For design, this means working with color values that correspond with tokens. For implementation, a color value will be a token that references a value. Learn more about design tokens.

Contents

Usage

FAB
Small FAB

Responsive layout
Behavior

contentChunks.altText: A floating action button over a typical UI

contentChunks.htmlValue: Usage

Use a FAB for the most important action on a screen. The FAB appears in front of all other content on screen, and is recognizable for its rounded shape and icon in the center.

Only use a FAB for presenting a screen's primary action.

The FAB can be aligned left, center, or right. It can be positioned above the navigation bar, or nested within the bar.

contentChunks.footer: Large FAB using dynamic color
contentChunks.altText: Example of large FAB

contentChunks.htmlValue:
There are 3 sizes of FAB:

  1. FAB
  2. Small FAB
  3. Large FAB

contentChunks.footer: 1. FAB  2. Small FAB  3. Large FAB
contentChunks.altText: 3 FAB examples

contentChunks.htmlValue: Anatomy

contentChunks.footer:
1. Container
2. Icon
contentChunks.altText: Example FAB container with icon

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Container

The FAB is typically displayed in a rounded square container. The product color scheme determines the FAB container color, which should contrast with the area behind the FAB.

contentChunks.footer: A FAB container color needs to stand out from its background.
contentChunks.altText: Example of FAB container shape

contentChunks.footer: Don't layer badges or other elements in front of a FAB.
contentChunks.altText: Example of badge overlay

contentChunks.footer: Ensure the FAB container color contrasts with the area behind it.
contentChunks.altText: Example of FAB color

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Icon

An icon in a FAB should be clear and understandable. On hover, FABs should display a tooltip with an accompanying icon text label.

A FAB shouldn't contain notifications or actions found elsewhere on a screen.

contentChunks.footer: Use clear and simple icons, such as Add, Message, or Edit. Ensure that a tooltip is available for clarity.
contentChunks.altText: 4 FABs with examples of clear icons

contentChunks.footer: Don’t use confusing or open-ended icons to symbolize less common actions like Gesture, Storm, or Local Florist.
contentChunks.altText: 4 FABs with examples of ambiguous icons

contentChunks.htmlValue: FAB
Use a FAB to represent the screen’s primary action.

contentChunks.footer: A FAB should present a screen’s primary action.
contentChunks.altText: Example of FAB on contrasting dark background

contentChunks.footer: Represent the most common primary action with a FAB, such as drafting a new email.
contentChunks.altText: Example FAB placed in the lower right of a screen

contentChunks.footer: FABs are not needed on every screen, such as when images represent primary actions.
contentChunks.altText: Example screen with no FAB

contentChunks.footer: Don't display multiple FABs on a single screen. Instead, consider using a menu or, in rare cases, pairing a small FAB with a default FAB.
contentChunks.altText: Multiple FABs on single screen

contentChunks.htmlValue: Small FAB

A small FAB is used for a secondary, supporting action, or in place of a default FAB on smaller screens.

One or more small FABs can be paired with a default FAB or extended FAB.

contentChunks.footer: If multiple important actions are necessary, use a small FAB for one of the actions.
contentChunks.altText: Example small FAB above an extended FAB on a maps screen

contentChunks.footer: Don’t use multiple extended FABs on one screen as it disrupts visual hierarchy
contentChunks.altText: Example of 2 extended FABs on a maps screen

contentChunks.htmlValue: Large FAB

A large FAB is useful when the layout calls for a clear and prominent primary action, and where a larger footprint would help the user engage. For example, when appearing on taller and larger device screens.

contentChunks.footer: Consider a large FAB when there is a clear action to take as part of a user’s flow.
contentChunks.altText: Example large FAB overlapping small amounts of content

contentChunks.footer: Don’t use a large FAB if its bigger size obscures important information on the screen. Instead, use a FAB.
contentChunks.altText: Example large FAB overlapping important contact information

contentChunks.htmlValue: Responsive layout

Desktop

A consistent position for FABs improves discoverability as it appears across a responsive range of layouts. For large screens, it’s recommended to place the FAB in the upper left region.

contentChunks.footer: Place the FAB in the upper left corner for large screens
contentChunks.altText: Diagram of a FAB in the upper left corner of a desktop screen

contentChunks.footer: A FAB can be used within a navigation component, such as a navigation rail or navigation drawer.
contentChunks.altText: Diagram of FAB set in the top of a navigation rail

contentChunks.footer: Individual components, such as cards, cannot each have their own FAB.
contentChunks.altText: Diagram with 8 FABs individually contained within 8 cards

contentChunks.htmlValue: Behavior

Appearing

When a FAB animates on screen, it expands outward from a central point. The icon within it may be animated as well.

While FABs should be relevant to screen content, they aren't attached to the surface on which content appears. FABs move separately from other UI elements because of their relative importance.

Screen transitions

FABs can morph to launch related actions. When a screen changes its layout, the FAB should disappear and reappear during the transition.

Reappearance

The FAB should only reappear if it's relevant to the new screen. It should reappear in the same position, if possible.

contentChunks.footer: FAB animating on screen
contentChunks.altText: Example of FAB expanding outward as screen expands

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Actions

A FAB can trigger an action either on the current screen, or it can perform an action that creates a new screen.

A FAB promotes an important, constructive action such as:

  • Create
  • Favorite
  • Share
  • Start a process

contentChunks.footer: Use FABs for primary, positive actions.
contentChunks.altText: 12 example FABs with icons representing positive actions

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Avoid using a FAB for minor or destructive actions, such as:

  • Archive or trash
  • Alerts or errors
  • Limited tasks like cutting text
  • Controls better suited to a toolbar (like controls to adjust volume or font color)

contentChunks.footer: Do not use FABs for minor, overflow, unclear, or destructive actions.
contentChunks.altText: 18 example FABs with icons representing positive actions

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Scrolling

FABs remain in place on scroll.

Extended FABs can collapse into a FAB on scroll and expand on reaching the bottom of the view.

contentChunks.footer: FABs stay in place above a scrolling background.
contentChunks.altText: Example of FAB on scrolling screen

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Moving across tabs

When tabs are present, the FAB should briefly disappear, then reappear when the new content moves into place. This shows that the FAB is not connected to any particular tab or destination.

contentChunks.footer: The FAB briefly disappears and reappears when moving between destinations or tabs.
Don't animate the FAB as if it is pinned to a particular destination or tab, as this horizontal motion implies.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Expanding

The FAB can expand and adapt to any shape, including a surface that is part of the app structure, or a surface that spans the entire screen.

contentChunks.footer: FABs can expand and adapt to any shape.
contentChunks.altText: Example of Compose FAB expanding into a draft email screen

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Accessibility guidelines coming soon

In progress: complete guidance for accessible interaction, keyboard navigation, labeling, and more. Learn more about accessibility.
